awd_titl_txt: Energy-harvesting Light Source Arrays from Colloidal Double-Heterojunction Nanorods
awd_abstract_narration:
With ever-increasing demand for more function and higher performance with reduced size and weight, fabrication of devices like smart phones and tablets are inevitably going to be more complex and more expensive. Their energy consumption, both in use and in manufacturing, will also increase accordingly. Recent advances to make semiconductors so small that their optical and electrical properties can be tuned by their size and shape are allowing simple ways to fabricate high-performance devices with high efficiencies and new capabilities. For example, such tiny semiconductor materials may be made to not only emit but also sense and harvest light, a feature that can be exploited to develop devices such as displays with pixels that can generate its own power through scavenging ambient light. This project aims to address the important challenge of how electrons/charges can be efficiently placed in and out of these tunable semiconductor materials – a critical first step in any light emitting and photovoltaic devices. The knowledge gained here will allow design and fabrication of high-performance LED pixel arrays with multiple capabilities such as solar energy harvesting and light sensing while simultaneously being a light source.  Multi-faceted challenges to be tackled here provide ample educational and training opportunities for the students involved, helping them be better prepared to become leaders in interdisciplinary fields. The PI is committed to building on the results of this project to enhance teaching and promote the benefits of emerging science and technologies.

Heterostructures of colloidal quantum dots provide opportunities to improve device performance and to usher in new capabilities. This project focuses on colloidal semiconductor nanorods that allow a double heterojunction to be formed on a quantum dot. These materials that the PI has recently developed have been shown to both emit and harvest light. They can also be solution processed, opening up opportunities for compact, energy-efficient multifunctional device arrays on arbitrary substrates that can pave new paths to next generation of display, lighting, communication, and related technologies. Incorporating these materials into electronic/optoelectronic devices requires the understanding of how interfacing materials, such as charge transport layers, affect carrier injection, extraction, separation, and recombination. Through a combination of studies on carrier dynamics and device physics, this project aims to elucidate how different electron and hole transport layers affect electroluminescence and photocurrent generation. The results of these efforts will guide the development of optimum interfaces for designing the next generation of electronic/optoelectronics devices with multiple functionality, especially those that can reduce energy consumption both in use and in manufacturing. The research efforts of this project will also help to create new lectures, experiments for undergraduate laboratory courses, and demonstration materials that will enhance classroom teaching and promote nanoscience and energy-efficient technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Colloidal quantum dots (QDs), in particular their heterostructures, are advancing multiple technological areas including imaging, displays, and solar energy conversion. In most of these applications, they are used as down-converters where photons of higher energies are absorbed by these materials and emitted at lower energies. The key advantages of quantum dots for these purposes are the tunability of emitted photon energy with QD size, the narrow linewidth of the emitted light, and high efficiency of the down-conversion process. These salient features also make QDs ideal candidates for electroluminescence, where light is generated from these materials through electrical means. Indeed, QDs have emerged as solution-processable LED materials and rapid improvements in their LED performance have been made over the last few years. Yet, many fundamental aspects about the device operating mechanisms remain under debate. Through the efforts of this project, new insights on capacitive charging and charge transport in QD LEDs have been gained. We have identified charging and diffusion of charged species that infiltrate the QD emitting layer from solution processing as a source of often-observed device-to-device variations in QD LEDs and related devices. This new understanding is necessary for resolving device-to-device variations, which is critical to address before a path to manufacturing of QD-LEDs for display, lighting and related applications can be realized.   

This project has also made advances in dual functioning light emitting and harvesting devices enabled by nanorods that incorporate QDs. New insights into charge injection, separation, and trapping processes in these materials and their devices have been gained. These insights have been exploited to improve photovoltaic response of LEDs of these nanorods while maintaining high efficiency of electroluminescence. This achievement overcomes the difficulty often imposed by the fact that improving photovoltaic response requires enhancing charge separation, which can be detrimental to electroluminescence that requires efficient recombination, rather than separation, of electrically generated charges.

Building on our accomplishments in anisotropic materials based on QDs, this project has also paved a path to systematically incorporating two or more QDs with variable size and aspect ratio into nanorods. These materials can impart new capabilities and even multiple capabilities that may allow broader application of QDs. For example, initial studies on these nanorods with two or more QDs have revealed an unusual color switching behavior that can be controlled by the number of electrons that are placed in them. Incorporating these multi-QD materials into devices such as those explored in this project may lead to interesting prospects of individual LED pixels that can switch between multiple colors and act as light harvesting device.

The research efforts of this project have also led to improvements in the laboratory courses on novel photovoltaics and low-dimensional electronics that the PI teaches. Students involved in this project have had educational, training, and mentoring opportunities that can help them be better prepared to become leaders especially in emerging technical fields.
